Basics of Functional Analysis

1. Topological Vector Spaces

1.1. Vector spaces [Rud-FA]

Def 1.1.1. Vector spaces

Let Φ stand for scalar field. A vector space over Φ is a set X, whose elements are called vectors, and in which two operations, addition and scalar multiplication, are defined, with the following familiar algebraic properties:

  1. Addition

    • Symmetric : x+y=y+x
    • Associative : x+(y+z)=(x+y)+z
    • Identity : 0∈X such that x+0=x, ∀x∈X
    • Inverse : ∀x∈X, ∃!(−x)∈X such that x+(−x)=0

  2. Scalar multiplication

    • Associative : α(βx)=(αβ)x
    • Identity : 1x=x

  3. Distributive laws

    • α(x+y)=αx+αy
    • (α+β)x=αx+βx

 

Note 1.1.2. Convention

If X is a vector space, A⊂X,B⊂X,x∈X, and λ∈Φ, the following notations will be used :

(1)x+A={x+a:a∈A}x−A={x−a:a∈A}A+B={a+b:a∈A, b∈B}λA={λa:a∈A}

 

Def 1.1.3. Convex

A set C⊂X is said to be convex if

(2)tC+(1−t)C⊂C(0≤t≤1)

 

Def 1.1.4. Balanced

A set B⊂X is said to be balanced if αB⊂B for every α∈Φ with |α|≤1

1.2. Topological Space [Rud-FA, Munk, Ball]

Def 1.2.1. Topology

A topology on a set X is a collection T of subsets of X having the following properties

  1. ∅∈T, X∈T
  2. The union of the elements of any subcollection of T is in T
  3. The intersection of the elements of any finite subcollection of T is in T

A set X for which a topology T has been specified is called a topological space and denote it as an ordered pair (X,T)

If (X,T) is a topological space, we say that a subset U of X is an open set of X if U∈T.

 

Def 1.2.2. Standard vocabularies of topology

  • A set C∈X is closed iff X∖C∈T
  • The closure C¯ of C is the intersection of all closed sets that contain C¯
  • The interior C∘ of C is the union of all open sets that are subsets of C
  • A neighborhood of a point p∈X is any open set that contains p
  • (X,T) is a Hausdorff space, and T is a Hausdorff topology, if distinct points of X have disjoint neighborhoods
  • A set K∈X is compact if every open cover of K has a finite subcover
  • A collection T′⊂T is a base for T if every member of T is a union of members of T′
  • A collection G of neighborhoods of a point p∈X is a local base at p if every neighborhood of p contains a member of G
  • If A⊂X and if S is the collection of all intersections A∩U, with U∈T, then S is a topology on A, as is easily verified; we call this the topology that A inherits from X
  • If a topology T is induced by a metric d we say that d and τ are compatible with each other
  • A sequence (xn) in a Hausdorff space X converges to a point x∈X (or limn→∞xn=x) if every neighborhood of x contains all but finitely many of the points xn

 

Def 1.2.3. Relative topology (= induced topology)

Let (X,T) be a topological space, and Y⊂X. Then sets of the form U=V∩Y for V∈T constitute a topology on Y, called the relative topology. (=induced topology or subspace topology)

 

Def 1.2.4. Product topology

Let X and Y be topological spaces. Then the sets of the form U×V, with U open in X and V open in Y form the basis of a topology on X×Y. This topology is called the product topology.

 

Prop 1.2.5. Universal property

Let X and Y be topological spaces, and let pX:X×Y→X and pY:X×Y→Y be the projections. Then the product topology is characterized by the following universal property :

For all topological spaces Z and maps f:Z→X×Y, f is continuous iff pX∘f and pY∘f are continuous.

1.3. Topological Vector Space [Rud-FA, Voi, Munk]

Def 1.3.1. Continuous

Let (X,τ), (Y,σ) be topological spaces, f:X→Y, x∈X. Then f is continuous at x if f−1(V) is a neighborhood of x, for all neighborhoods V of f(x).

The mapping f is called continuous, if f is continuous at every x∈X, and this is equivalent to the property that f−1(V)∈τ for all V∈σ.

The mapping f is a homeomorphism, if f is continuous and bijective, and the inverse f−1:Y→X is also continuous.

 

Thm 1.3.2. (Useful thm for continuous)

Let X and Y be topological spaces, f:X→Y. Then the following are equivalent.

  1. f is continuous.
  2. For each x∈X and each neighborhood V of f(x), there is a neighborhood U of x such that f(U)⊂V

proof

  • 1→2 : Since f is continuous, f−1(V) is a neighborhood of x for every neighborhood V of f(x). Thus we put U=f−1(V) then f(U)⊂V.

  • 2→1 : Let V be an open set of Y and x be a point of f−1(V). Then since f(x)∈V, V is a neighborhood of f(x). From 2, there is a neighborhood Ux such that f(Ux)⊂V. It means Ux⊂f−1(V) for every point x∈f−1(V). Therefore we can write

    (3)f−1(V)=⋃x∈f−1(V)Ux

    Thus, it is a neighborhood of x and it is satisfied for all x∈X. Therefore f is continuous.

 

Def 1.3.3. Topological vector spaces

Suppose τ is a topology on a vector space X such that

  • every point of X is a closed set
  • the vector space operations are continuous with respect to τ

Under these conditions, τ is said to be a vector topology or linear topology on X, and (X,τ) is a topological vector space.

 

Example 1.3.4.

  • A vector space X with the trivial topology τ={∅,X} is a topological vector space

    1. Addition can be denoted by a function f:X×X→X. Let z=f(x,y) and consider U(z) as a neighborhood of z. But τ includes only ∅ or X thus, Uz=X. Since X is a vector space, the inverse image of addition is whole X×X. It is a neighborhood of (x,y) whatever topology of X×X.
    2. Scalar multiplication is can be denoted as a function g:Φ×X→X. By the same logic as above, it is also continuous.

 

  • Normed and semi-normed spaces are topological vector spaces.

    1. Let z=f(x,y)=x+y then the neighborhoods of z can be represented by canonical metric U(z,ϵ)={u|‖u−z‖<ϵ}. From Thm 1.3.2, we will prove that for given ϵ>0 there exist ϵ′>0 and ϵ″>0 such that f(U(x,ϵ′),U(y,ϵ″))⊂U(z,ϵ). We know

      (4)f(U(x,ϵ′),U(y,ϵ″))={u+v|‖u−x‖<ϵ′, ‖v−y‖<ϵ′}

      And since z=x+y, we can find as follows.

      (5)‖u+v−z‖=‖(u−x)+(v−y)‖≤‖u−x‖+‖v−y‖<ϵ′+ϵ″

      Then if we take any positive number ϵ′,ϵ″ such that ϵ′,ϵ″<ϵ2 then proof is complete.

    2. Let z=g(α,x)=αx then find ϵ′ and ϵ″ such that g(B(α,ϵ′),U(x,ϵ″))⊂U(z,ϵ) for any ϵ>0.

      (6)g(B(α,ϵ′),U(x,ϵ″))={βu||β−α|<ϵ′, ‖u−x‖<ϵ″}

      And since z=αx,

      (7)‖βu−z‖=‖(β−α)(u−x)+(β−α)x+α(u−x)‖<ϵ′ϵ″+ϵ′∥x∥+|α|ϵ″

      WLOG ϵ′=ϵ″ then we should find ϵ′ such that ϵ′2+(∥x∥+|a|)ϵ′<ϵ. Then the answer is

      (8)ϵ′<(∥x∥+|α|)2+4ϵ−(∥x∥+|α|)2

 

Note 1.3.5. (Translation & Scale)

Let X be a topological vector space. Associate to each a∈X and to each scalar λ≠0 the translation operator Ta and the scale operator Mλ, by the formulas

(9)Ta(x)=a+x,Mλ(x)=λx(x∈X)

 

Prop 1.3.6. (Invariance)

Ta and Mλ are homeomorphisms of X onto X.

Proof

  • Injective :
  • Ta(x1)=Ta(x2)⇒a+x1=a+x2⇒x1=x2
  • Mλ(x1)=Mλ(x2)⇒λx1=λx2⟹λ≠0x1=x2
  • Surjective :
  • Ta(X)=a+X=X
  • Mλ(X)=λX=X
  • Continuous :
  • Ta(x)=(pX∘f)(x,a) where f(x,y)=x+y. We know f is continuous because X is topological vector space, thus from universal property, Ta is continuous.
  • Mλ(x) is continuous by same reason.
  • Continuity of inverse :
  • Ta−1=T−a and it is trivially continuous
  • Mλ−1=M1/λ and it is trivially continuous

 

The meaning of this proposition is that every vector topology τ is translation-invariant (or simply invariant). Thus, a set U⊂X is open iff each of its translates a+U is open. Therefore τ is completely determined any local base.

In the vector space context, the term local base will always mean a local base at 0.

 

Note 1.3.7. (Types of topological vector spaces)

  • X is locally convex if there is a local base B whose members are convex.
  • X is locally bounded if 0 has a bounded neighborhood.
  • X is locally compact if 0 has a neighborhood whose closure is compact.
  • X is metrizable if τ is compatible with some metric d.
  • X is an F-space if its topology τ is induced by a complete invariant metric d.
  • X is a Frechet space if X is a locally convex F-space.
  • X is normable if a norm exists on X such that the metric induced by the norm is compatible with τ
  • Normed spaces and Banach spaces
  • X has the Heine-Borel property if every closed and bounded subset of X is compact.

 

Note 1.3.8. (Properties of a topological vector space)

  1. If X is locally bounded, then X has a countable local base.
  2. X is metrizable iff X has a countable local base.
  3. X is normable iff X is locally convex and locally bounded.
  4. X has finite dimension iff X is locally compact.
  5. If a locally bounded space X has the Heine-Borel property, then X has a finite dimension.

1.4. Separation Properties [Rud-FA, Munk]

Lem 1.4.1.

If W is a neighborhood of 0 in X, then there is a neighborhood U of 0 which is symmetric (in the sense that U=−U) and which satisfies U+U⊂W.

 

Proof

Since 0+0=0 and addition is continuous, there exist neighborhoods V1,V2 of 0 such that V1+V2⊂W for any neighborhood W of 0. Now, let U=V1∩V2∩(−V1)∩(−V2) then since topology is invariant under addition and scalar multiplication, U is still a neighborhood of 0 and satisfies above condition.

 

Thm 1.4.2.

Let X be a topological vectors space and K be a compact subset and C be a closed subset of X such that K∩C=∅. Then 0 has a neighborhood V such that

(10)(K+V)∩(C+V)=∅

Proof

First, let K=∅ then since K+V=∅, above theorem is satisfied.

Next, let K≠∅ then there is a point x∈K. Since K and C are disjoint, x∈X∖C. Because X∖C is open, there always exists a neighborhood of x such that x∈W⊂X∖C. And since Tx (translation operator with respect to x) is continuous, for all neighborhood W of x, there exists a neighborhood W′ of 0 such that x+W′⊂W.

From Lem 1.4.1, we can find a symmetric neighborhood U of 0 such that U+U⊂W′ for any neighborhood W′ of 0. And since U is a neighborhood of 0 too, we can find a symmetric neighborhood U′ of 0 such that U′+U′+U′+U′⊂W′. And we know the property if A+B⊂C then A⊂C, thus it implies U′+U′+U′⊂W′.

Summing up above two paragraphs, we can find the fact that 0 has a symmetric neighborhood Vx such that x+Vx+Vx+Vx⊂X∖C. It means (x+Vx+Vx+Vx)∩C=∅ and more specifically, for any c∈C, we can't find any u,v,w∈Vx such that c=x+u+v+w. And it also means we can't find any u,v∈Vx such that c+(−w)=x+u+v for any c,w. From the symmetricity of Vx, we can write this as (x+Vx+Vx)∩(C+Vx)=∅.

Since x+Vx is a open neighborhood of x∈K, ⋃x∈K(x+Vx) is an open cover of K. Because K is compact, it should have a finite point {xi}i=1n⊂K such that K⊂⋃i=1n(xi+Vxi). Now, let V=⋂i=1nVxi then we can get :

(11)K+V⊂⋃i=1n(xi+Vxi+V)⊂⋃i=1n(xi+Vxi+Vxi)

And we know xi+Vxi+Vxi⊂X∖(C+Vxi), then we can get :

(12)⋃i=1n(xi+Vxi+Vxi)⊂⋃i=1n(X∖(C+Vxi))⊂X∖(C+⋂i=1nVxi)=X∖(C+V)

Therefore we can always find V such that (K+V)∩(C+V)=∅.

 

Since K+V is open, K+V― does not intersect C+V.

 

Note 1.4.3.

Let X be a topological vector space then every finite subset of X is compact.

 

Thm 1.4.4.

If B is a local base for a topological vector space X, then every member of B contains the closure of some member of B.

 

Proof

Let B∈B. Let K={0} and C=X∖B. Then from Thm 1.4.2, there exists V which is a symmetric neighborhood of 0 such that

(13)V―∩(C+V)=∅

It means V―⊂X∖(X∖B+V)⊂X∖(X∖B)=B. From the definition of local base, there exists a neighborhood W∈B of 0 such that

(14)W⊂V⊂V―⊂B

Since V― is closed, W―⊂V―⊂B.

Def 1.4.5. (Hausdorff)

The topological space (X,τ) is a Hausdorff space and τ is a Hausdorff topology, if distinct points of X have disjoint neighborhoods.

 

Thm 1.4.6. (Hausdorff separation axiom for TVS)

Every topological vector space is a Hausdorff space.

 

Proof

Since every single point is compact and closed, use Thm 1.4.2 for K={x} and C={y} where x,y are any distinct points in X. Then proof is complete.

 

Lem 1.4.7. (Properties of Closure)

Let A be a subset of the topological space X.

  1. Then x∈A¯ iff every open set U containing x intersects A.
  2. Supposing the topology of X is given by a basis, then x∈A¯ iff every basis element B containing x intersects A.

 

Proof

  1. Consider contrapositive of the statement : x∉A¯⇔∃U∋x such that U∩A=∅. Since x∈X∖A¯ and X∖A¯ is open, there exists an open neighborhood U of x such that x∈U⊂X∖A¯. Then proof is complete.
  2. Consider B is a base. Then every open sets in X should be represented by an union of its elements. Thus, proof is trivial.

 

Thm 1.4.8. (Properties of subsets of TVS)

Let X be a topological vector space.

  1. If A⊂X then A―=⋂(A+V), where V runs through all neighborhoods of 0.
  2. If A⊂X and B⊂X, then A―+B―⊂A+B―.
  3. If Y is a subspace of X, so is Y―.
  4. If C is a convex subset of X, so are C― and C∘.
  5. If B is a balanced subset of X, so is B―; if also 0∈B∘ then B∘ is balanced.
  6. If E is a bounded subset of X, so is E―.

 

Proof

  1. From Lem 1.4.7, suppose x∈A¯, then (x−V)∩A≠∅ for every neighborhood V of 0. It means for any v∈V, there exists a∈A such that x−v=a. It implies, x∈A+V for every such V. Thus, A¯⊂A+V for every neighborhood V of 0. Therefore A¯⊂⋂(A+V). Conversely, consider contrapositive : suppose x∉A¯. Then, from Lem 1.4.7, there exists a neighborhood V of 0 such that (x−V)∩A=∅. It means x∉A+V, therefore x∉⋂(A+V).
